dataset.description: Gold pharmacist scenarios for LLM evaluation (enriched for deterministic scoring).

failure_cases.question: 5-year-old (18 kg) with acute otitis media. What is the amoxicillin dose and volume using 400 mg/5 mL suspension?
failure_cases.generated_answer: For a 5-year-old weighing 18 kg with acute otitis media, the recommended dose of amoxicillin is 90 mg/kg/day, given twice daily. This equates to approximately 1620 mg per day. Using the 400 mg/5 mL suspension, the per-dose volume would be approximately 10 mL (rounded), with a maximum daily dose of 4 g. This dosing regimen is supported by [chunk_F134628::3]. No renal adjustment is necessary if the patient has normal renal function. However, it's important to note that this dosing is considered high-dose and is recommended for severe illness, those who have received amoxicillin in the past 30 days, treatment failure at 48 to 72 hours on first-line therapy, and when coverage for beta-lactamase positive H. influenzae and M. catarrhalis is needed. Always consult current clinical guidance for the most up-to-date information.
failure_cases.expected_answer: Amoxicillin 90 mg/kg/day divided q12h → 810 mg per dose (≈10.1 mL of 400 mg/5 mL), round to 10 mL per dose; max 4 g/day.
key_points_missing: Volume ≈10.1 mL from 400 mg/5 mL (80 mg/mL); rounding to 10 mL OK

key_points_found: No renal adjustment if normal function
key_points_missing: Volume ≈10.1 mL from 400 mg/5 mL (80 mg/mL); rounding to 10 mL OK

failure_cases.question: 12 kg child with fever: acetaminophen dose and volume using 160 mg/5 mL?
failure_cases.generated_answer:
For a 12 kg child, the recommended dose of acetaminophen is 15 mg/kg, which equates to 180 mg per dose. Using a liquid formulation with a concentration of 32 mg/mL, the volume would be approximately 5.625 mL per dose. The maximum daily dose should not exceed 75 mg/kg/day or 4 grams, whichever is less.

Please refer to the pediatric dosing section for more detailed information [chunk_acetaminophen-paracetamol-dextromethorphan-and-phenylephrine-drug-information::F5093686::0]. It's important to note that when calculating the maximum daily dose, consider all sources of acetaminophen and all routes of administration. Do not exceed the maximum recommended daily dose.
failure_cases.expected_answer: Acetaminophen 15 mg/kg/dose q6h (range 10–15 mg/kg q4–6h) → 180 mg per dose ≈5.6 mL of 160 mg/5 mL; max 75 mg/kg/day (900 mg), and ≤4 g absolute.
key_points_missing: q4–6h acceptable; target q6h in calc
q4–6h acceptable; target q6h in calc

failure_cases.question: 12 kg child with fever: ibuprofen dose and volume using 100 mg/5 mL?
failure_cases.generated_answer: <s> [OUT] For a 12 kg child with fever, the recommended oral ibuprofen dose is 10 mg/kg every 6 to 8 hours, which equates to 120 mg per dose. Using a 100 mg/5 mL suspension, this would require 6 mL (100 mg/5 mL × 6 mL = 120 mg). The maximum daily dose is 40 mg/kg/day (480 mg). Ibuprofen is contraindicated in infants younger than 6 months and should be used with caution in patients with renal impairment or dehydration [Chunk ibuprofen-drug-information::F181483::0, Chunk ibuprofen-drug-information::F181483::1]. [/OUT]
failure_cases.expected_answer: Ibuprofen 10 mg/kg/dose q6–8h → 120 mg per dose (6 mL of 100 mg/5 mL); max 40 mg/kg/day (480 mg). Avoid if <6 months or dehydrated/renal issues.

failure_cases.question: Elderly patient with nonvalvular AF: 82 years, 58 kg, SCr 1.6 mg/dL. What apixaban dose?
failure_cases.expected_answer: Apixaban 2.5 mg BID (meets 2 of 3: age ≥80, weight ≤60 kg, SCr ≥1.5). Avoid with strong CYP3A4/P-gp inhibitors.

failure_cases.question: 85 kg adult with acute DVT: What is the enoxaparin treatment dose (normal renal function)?
failure_cases.generated_answer: For an 85 kg adult with normal renal function (CrCl >30 mL/minute), the recommended enoxaparin treatment dose for acute DVT is 1 mg/kg every 12 hours, as per [chunk_165080::7]. This equates to a per-dose of 85 mg. However, it's important to note that in patients with venous thromboembolism (VTE) and without cancer, oral anticoagulants are preferred over LMWH (unless LMWH is used as initial parenteral anticoagulation prior to dabigatran, edoxaban, or while initiating warfarin) [chunk_165080::6]. As always, patient-specific factors and institutional protocols should be considered when determining the appropriate dose.
failure_cases.expected_answer: Enoxaparin 1 mg/kg SC q12h → 85 mg per dose (or 1.5 mg/kg once daily as alternative). If CrCl <30 mL/min: 1 mg/kg once daily.

failure_cases.question: Type 2 diabetes patient with eGFR 28 mL/min/1.73 m². Can we use metformin?
failure_cases.generated_answer: Based on the provided context, the use of metformin is contraindicated in patients with an eGFR less than 30 mL/min/1.73 m². For eGFR between 30 and 45 mL/min/1.73 m², it is not recommended to initiate metformin therapy. If metformin therapy is continued, a dosage reduction and monitoring of renal function every 3 months are recommended ([chunk_F176387], [chunk_F50990977], [chunk_F6213570]). The context does not provide information about the use of metformin in patients with an eGFR between 45 and 60 mL/min/1.73 m². For further guidance, please consult current clinical practice guidelines.
failure_cases.expected_answer: No—contraindicated at eGFR <30. If 30–45, generally avoid initiation; if continuing, reduce dose and monitor. Avoid in hepatic impairment.
key_points_missing: 30–45: avoid initiation; if continuing, reduce & monitor
30–45: avoid initiation; if continuing, reduce & monitor

failure_cases.question: Uncomplicated cystitis: Should we use nitrofurantoin if eGFR is 25?
failure_cases.generated_answer: Based on the provided context, nitrofurantoin should not be used for uncomplicated cystitis if the eGFR is 25, as the manufacturer contraindicates its use in CrCl <60 mL/minute [chunk_201969:1]. The Beers Criteria also recommends avoiding nitrofurantoin in geriatric patients with a CrCl, suggesting it may not be effective or safe in such cases. For uncomplicated cystitis, fosfomycin is an alternative option for women with susceptible strains of E. coli and Enterococcus faecalis [chunk_174299:0]. However, it's important to note that the context does not provide information on fosfomycin's safety and efficacy for patients with eGFR <30. Always consult current clinical guidance for the most up-to-date information.
failure_cases.expected_answer: Avoid nitrofurantoin when eGFR/CrCl <30 mL/min due to low urinary levels and toxicity risk.

failure_cases.question: Patient on warfarin needs TMP-SMX for UTI. Any interaction and what should we do?
failure_cases.generated_answer: There is a major drug interaction between warfarin and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX). This interaction is due to CYP2C9 inhibition by TMP-SMX, which may increase warfarin's anticoagulant effect [capecitabine-drug-information::F5708655::0]. Therefore, it is recommended to either avoid using TMP-SMX in patients on warfarin or closely monitor the international normalized ratio (INR) and adjust the warfarin dose as necessary. [warfarin-drug-information::F234837::4]
failure_cases.expected_answer: Major interaction (CYP2C9 inhibition + gut flora). Avoid if possible; otherwise increase INR monitoring and reduce warfarin dose.
key_points_missing: Action: avoid or close INR monitoring with dose reduction
Action: avoid or close INR monitoring with dose reduction

failure_cases.question: Patient on atorvastatin needs clarithromycin. What’s the risk and action?
failure_cases.generated_answer: <s> [OUT] Clarithromycin is a strong CYP3A4 inhibitor that increases atorvastatin serum concentration, raising the risk of atorvastatin toxicity (e.g., myopathy, rhabdomyolysis). If the combination is unavoidable, limit atorvastatin to a maximum dose of 20 mg/day and monitor closely for signs of toxicity [Chunk atorvastatin-drug-information::F137634::3, Chunk amlodipine-and-atorvastatin-drug-information::F134112::6, Chunk omeprazole-clarithromycin-and-amoxicillin-copackaged-drug-information::F14471021::5, Chunk lansoprazole-amoxicillin-and-clarithromycin-copackaged-drug-information::F186882::5, Chunk clarithromycin-drug-information::F152340::4].
failure_cases.expected_answer: Major interaction (strong CYP3A4 inhibitor). Avoid coadministration; if unavoidable, hold atorvastatin or limit to the lowest dose and monitor for myopathy.
key_points_missing: Action: avoid; if unavoidable hold or use lowest dose with monitoring
Action: avoid; if unavoidable hold or use lowest dose with monitoring

failure_cases.question: Starting linezolid in a patient on sertraline. Is this safe?
failure_cases.generated_answer: Based on the provided context, the use of linezolid in a patient on sertraline (an SSRI) may pose a significant risk due to the potential for serotonin syndrome. This is because linezolid has MAOI activity, which can increase serotonin levels [chunk_188931::1]. The risk is major, and it is recommended to avoid the combination. If the use of linezolid is unavoidable, close monitoring for signs and symptoms of serotonin syndrome is necessary [chunk_188931::1]. It is also important to note that discontinuing sertraline 2 weeks prior to linezolid administration is recommended to mitigate the risk [chunk_166177::3, chunk_160435::4, chunk_166284::4].
failure_cases.expected_answer: Major interaction: risk of serotonin syndrome (linezolid has MAOI activity). Avoid; if benefits outweigh risks, withhold SSRI or monitor very closely.
key_points_missing: Action: avoid; or stop SSRI/close monitoring if unavoidable
Action: avoid; or stop SSRI/close monitoring if unavoidable

failure_cases.question: Patient on digoxin will start amiodarone. What’s the interaction management?
failure_cases.generated_answer: In the provided context, it is stated that Amiodarone may increase the serum concentration of Digoxin [chunk_digoxin-drug-information::F160110::8]. This interaction is classified as major (Risk D: Consider therapy modification). The mechanism is likely due to P-gp inhibition. If a patient is on both Digoxin and Amiodarone, it is recommended to reduce the Digoxin dose by 30-50% and closely monitor Digoxin levels and ECG. [chunk_digoxin-drug-information::F160110::8] and [chunk_dronedarone-drug-information::F7907323::10] provide more details on this interaction. However, it's important to note that the context does not specify the exact dosage adjustments for the Amiodarone-Digoxin interaction, so further consultation with a healthcare professional is advised.
failure_cases.expected_answer: Major interaction (P-gp inhibition). Reduce digoxin dose by ~30–50% and monitor levels/ECG.

key_points_found: Action: reduce dose ~30–50% + monitor levels and ECG

failure_cases.question: COVID-19 patient asks for Paxlovid dosing and interaction checks.
failure_cases.generated_answer:
I'm unable to provide a specific dosing or interaction check for Paxlovid as it is not mentioned in the provided context. However, I can share the dosing information for Paxil (paroxetine) based on the given context.

For COVID-19 patients, I recommend consulting current clinical guidance for Paxlovid, as it is not mentioned in the provided context.

For Paxil, the dosing varies depending on the condition and age group:
- For adults with Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD), and Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD), the initial dose is 20 mg once daily, with potential increases by 10 mg/day increments at 1-week intervals, up to a maximum of 50 mg/day for adults and 40 mg/day for geriatric patients [chunk_F206599, chunk_F206600].

Regarding drug-drug interactions, potentially significant interactions may exist, requiring dose or frequency adjustment, additional monitoring, and/or selection of alternative therapy. Consult the drug interactions database for more detailed information [chunk_F155528].

Please refer to the FDA-approved medication guide for the specific Paxil product you are considering [chunk_F7874764]. For Paxlovid, I strongly advise consulting current clinical guidance to ensure safe and effective use.
failure_cases.expected_answer: ABSTAIN. Not in ≤2018 corpus; recency-sensitive therapy. Advise consulting current guidance/pharmacist.

failure_cases.question: What is the current first-line pharmacologic therapy per latest hypertension guidelines?
failure_cases.generated_answer: Based on the provided context, the latest hypertension guidelines from 2014 (JNC8) suggest that pharmacologic treatment to lower blood pressure should be initiated for various patient groups, including those aged 60 and older with a systolic blood pressure (SBP) of 150 mm Hg or higher, and those under 60 with an SBP of 140 mm Hg or higher. However, it is important to note that the JNC8 guidelines are outdated, and current guidelines may provide more up-to-date recommendations. For pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), the latest guidelines from the Fifth World Symposium on Pulmonary Hypertension (WSPH) and the American College of Chest Physicians (ACCP) recommend continuous IV epoprostenol as first-line therapy in PAH patients with WHO-FC IV symptoms (WSPH [Gailè 2013], ACCP [Taichman 2014]). Therefore, it is crucial to consult the most recent hypertension guidelines for current treatment recommendations. [recency_risk = true]
failure_cases.expected_answer: ABSTAIN if asked for ‘current’ guidance (2018 corpus includes JNC8/2014). Flag recency risk.

Dosing: Pediatric

(For additional information see "Amoxicillin and clavulanate: Pediatric drug information")

Note: Dose is based on the amoxicillin component. Dose and frequency are product specific; not all products are interchangeable. Using a product with the incorrect amoxicillin:clavulanate ratio could result in subtherapeutic clavulanic acid concentrations or severe diarrhea.

Usual dosage range:

Infants <3 months: Oral: Amoxicillin 30 mg/kg/day divided every 12 hours using the 125 mg per 5 mL suspension only

Infants ≥3 months, Children, and Adolescents <40 kg: Oral: Immediate release:

Mild to moderate infections: Amoxicillin 25 mg/kg/day in divided doses twice daily (using the 200 mg per 5 mL or 400 mg per 5 mL suspension or 200 mg or 400 mg chewable tablets) or amoxicillin 20 mg/kg/day in divided doses 3 times daily (using the 125 mg per 5 mL or 250 mg per 5 mL suspension) (maximum single dose: 500 mg amoxicillin)

context_chunks.snippet: Severe infections: Amoxicillin 45 mg/kg/day in divided doses twice daily (using the 200 mg per 5 mL or 400 mg per 5 mL suspension or 200 mg or 400 mg chewable tablets) (maximum single dose: Amoxicillin 875 mg) or amoxicillin 40 mg/kg/day in…

Immediate release: Amoxicillin 875 mg every 12 hours (using the 875 mg tablet; if difficulty swallowing, the 200 mg per 5 mL or 400 mg per 5 mL suspension may be used) or amoxicillin 500 mg every 8 hours (using the 500 mg tablet; if difficulty swallowing, the 125 mg per 5 mL or 250 mg per 5 mL suspension may be used).

Indication-specific dosing:

Standard dose: Amoxicillin 45 mg/kg/day divided every 12 hours for 10 to 14 days (using the 200 mg per 5 mL or 400 mg per 5 mL suspension or 200 mg or 400 mg chewable tablets only) (IDSA [Chow 2012])

High dose (off-label dose): Amoxicillin 90 mg/kg/day divided every 12 hours for 10 to 14 days (using the 600 mg per 5 mL suspension only). Note: Use recommended in the following: If initial therapy fails (as second-line therapy), in areas with high endemic rates of penicillin-nonsusceptible S. pneumoniae, those with severe infections, daycare attendance, age <2 years, recent hospitalization, antibiotic use within the past month, or who are immunocompromised (IDSA [Chow 2012]).

• Elderly: Systemic exposure is increased ~32% in patients >65 years of age; however, dose reductions are not required. Dosage reduction is recommended for patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation who are ≥80 years of age and either weigh ≤60 kg or with a serum creatinine ≥1.5 mg/dL.

Other warnings/precautions:

• Appropriate use: In hemodynamically unstable patients with acute PE or patients with PE requiring thrombolysis or pulmonary embolectomy, the use of apixaban is not recommended as an alternative to unfractionated heparin for initial treatment.

• Body weight: Systemic exposure may be increased by 20% to 30% in patients <50 kg and decreased by 20% to 30% in patients >120 kg; dosage reduction is recommended for patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation weighing ≤60 kg and either ≥80 years of age or with a serum creatinine ≥1.5 mg/dL.

context_chunks.text: • Renal impairment: Systemic exposure increases with worsening renal function. Bleeding risk may be increased in severe renal impairment (CrCl <15 to 29 mL/minute); use with caution. Patients with significant renal impairment (eg, CrCl <30 mL/minute) were excluded from clinical trials. Dosage reduction is recommended for patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation and 2 of the 3 following risk factors: Serum creatinine ≥1.5 mg/dL, age ≥80 years, or weight ≤60 kg. Compared to warfarin, apixaban has been shown to be associated with less major bleeding among all ranges of estimated GFRs as determined by initial serum creatinine; however, patients with a serum creatinine >2.5 mg/dL or CrCl <25 mL/minute (as determined by Cockcroft-Gault equation) were excluded from the analysis (Hohnloser 2012). Use with caution in patients on hemodialysis; limited information is available. In patients who develop acute kidney injury during use, closely monitor or consider switching to an alternative anticoagulant due to an increased risk of bleeding in this population (AHA [Raval 2017]).

context_chunks.text:
Dialysis: Enoxaparin has not been FDA approved for use in dialysis patients. Its elimination is primarily via the renal route. Serious bleeding complications have been reported with use in patients who are dialysis dependent or have severe renal failure. LMWH administration at fixed doses without monitoring has greater unpredictable anticoagulant effects in patients with chronic kidney disease. If used, dosages should be reduced and anti-Xa levels frequently monitored, as accumulation may occur with repeated doses. Many clinicians would not use enoxaparin in this population especially without timely anti-Xa levels.

Hemodialysis: Not dialyzable (NCS/SCCM [Frontera 2016]). Supplemental dose is not necessary.

Peritoneal dialysis: Significant drug removal is unlikely based on physiochemical characteristics.

context_chunks.snippet: • Renal impairment: Use with caution in patients with renal failure; dosage adjustment needed if CrCl <30 mL/minute.  Special populations:  • Elderly: Use with caution in the elderly; delayed elimination may occur. Dosage alteration/adjustm…
context_chunks.text:
• Renal impairment: Use with caution in patients with renal failure; dosage adjustment needed if CrCl <30 mL/minute.

Special populations:

• Elderly: Use with caution in the elderly; delayed elimination may occur. Dosage alteration/adjustment may be required (eg, omission of IV bolus in acute STEMI in patients ≥75 years of age).

• Low weight patients: Risk of bleeding may be increased in women <45 kg and in men <57 kg.

• Obesity: Safety and efficacy of prophylactic dosing of enoxaparin has not been established in patients who are obese (>30 kg/m2) nor is there a consensus regarding dosage adjustments; monitor closely for signs/symptoms of thromboembolism. Anti-Xa levels are increased to appropriate levels when enoxaparin is dosed on actual body weight in obese patients weighing up to 144 kg (Sanderink 2002). Monitoring of anti-Xa levels 4 hours after the dose may be warranted. The American College of Chest Physicians Practice Guidelines suggest consulting with a pharmacist regarding dosing in bariatric surgery patients and other obese patients who may require higher doses of LMWH (ACCP [Gould 2012]).

• Hepatic impairment: The manufacturer recommends to generally avoid use in patients with hepatic impairment due to potential for lactic acidosis. However, continued use of metformin in patients with diabetes with liver dysfunction, including cirrhosis, may be associated with a survival benefit in carefully selected patients (Brackett 2010; Crowley 2017; Zhang 2014).

• Renal impairment: Metformin is substantially excreted by the kidney; assess renal function prior to initiation of therapy and periodically thereafter using eGFR. The risk of metformin accumulation and lactic acidosis increases with degree of renal impairment. Use of alogliptin/metformin combination product is not recommended in patients with eGFR 30 to 60 mL/minute/1.73 m2 and is contraindicated in patients with eGFR <30 mL/minute/1.73 m2. Use of concomitant medications that may affect renal function (ie, affect tubular secretion) may also affect metformin disposition. Metformin should be withheld in patients with dehydration and/or prerenal azotemia.

• Stress-related states: It may be necessary to discontinue metformin and administer insulin if the patient is exposed to stress (fever, trauma, infection, surgery).

failure_analysis.question: Type 2 diabetes patient with eGFR 28 mL/min/1.73 m². Can we use metformin?
failure_analysis.generated_answer: Based on the provided context, the use of metformin is contraindicated in patients with an eGFR less than 30 mL/min/1.73 m². For eGFR between 30 and 45 mL/min/1.73 m², it is not recommended to initiate metformin therapy. If metformin therapy is continued, a dosage reduction and monitoring of renal function every 3 months are recommended ([chunk_F176387], [chunk_F50990977], [chunk_F6213570]). The context does not provide information about the use of metformin in patients with an eGFR between 45 and 60 mL/min/1.73 m². For further guidance, please consult current clinical practice guidelines.

Dosing: Adult

Cystitis, acute uncomplicated, treatment:

Nitrofurantoin monohydrate/macrocrystals (Macrobid): Oral: 100 mg twice daily for 5 days (Gupta 2011; Gupta 2007).

Nitrofurantoin macrocrystals (Furadantin, Macrodantin): Oral: 50 to 100 mg every 6 hours; administer for 7 days or at least 3 days after obtaining sterile urine.

UTI, prophylaxis: Nitrofurantoin macrocrystals (Furadantin, Macrodantin): Oral: 50 to 100 mg once daily at bedtime.

context_chunks.text:
• Superinfection: Prolonged use may result in fungal or bacterial superinfection, including C. difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD) and pseudomembranous colitis; CDAD has been observed >2 months postantibiotic treatment.

Disease-related concerns:

• Hemolytic anemia: Use caution in patients with G6PD deficiency; may be at increased risk for hemolytic anemia. Discontinue therapy if occurs.

• Renal impairment: Urinary nitrofurantoin concentrations are variable in patients with impaired renal function. The manufacturer contraindicates use in CrCl <60 mL/minute; however, limited data suggest nitrofurantoin is safe and effective for short-term treatment of uncomplicated UTI in patients with CrCl 30 to 60 mL/minute (Oplinger 2013; Santos 2016; Singh 2015). The Beers Criteria recommends avoiding use in geriatric patients ≥65 years with a CrCl <30 mL/minute (Beers Criteria [AGS 2015]).

Concurrent drug therapy issues:

• Drug-drug interactions: Potentially significant interactions may exist, requiring dose or frequency adjustment, additional monitoring, and/or selection of alternative therapy. Consult drug interactions database for more detailed information.

Use

Uncomplicated urinary tract infections: Treatment of uncomplicated urinary tract infections (acute cystitis) in women due to susceptible strains of Escherichia coli and Enterococcus faecalis.

Limitations of use: Not indicated for the treatment of pyelonephritis or perinephric abscess. If persistence or reappearance of bacteriuria occurs after treatment with fosfomycin, other therapeutic agents should be selected.

End stage renal disease (ESRD) or hemodialysis: Use is contraindicated.

Dosing: Adult

Note: Weight-based dosing recommendations are based on the trimethoprim (TMP) component. Each double-strength tablet contains TMP 160 mg and sulfamethoxazole (SMX) 800 mg. Each single-strength tablet contains TMP 80 mg and SMX 400 mg. The undiluted IV solution contains TMP 16 mg per mL and SMX 80 mg per mL. IV solutions must be diluted in D5W prior to use. Diluted IV solutions have limited stability and can precipitate unpredictably; refer to a detailed IV compatibility reference.

General dosing guidelines:

Oral: 1 to 2 double-strength tablets every 12 to 24 hours. Note: Serum creatinine and potassium concentrations should be monitored in outpatients receiving high-dose therapy (>5 mg/kg TMP component/day) (Gentry 2013)

IV: 8 to 20 mg (TMP component)/kg/day divided every 6 to 12 hours

context_chunks.snippet: Pharmacodynamics/Kinetics  Absorption: Oral: Rapid; almost completely (90% to 100%)  Distribution: Both SMX and TMP distribute to middle ear fluid, sputum, vaginal fluid; TMP also distributes into bronchial secretions  Vd: TMP:  Newborns: ~…
context_chunks.text:
Pharmacodynamics/Kinetics

Absorption: Oral: Rapid; almost completely (90% to 100%)

Distribution: Both SMX and TMP distribute to middle ear fluid, sputum, vaginal fluid; TMP also distributes into bronchial secretions

Vd: TMP:

Newborns: ~2.7 L/kg (range: 1.3 to 4.1 hours) (Springer 1982)

Infants: 1.5 L/kg (Hoppu 1989)

Children 1 to 10 years: 0.86 to 1 L/kg (Hoppu 1987)

Adults: ~1.3 L/kg (Hoppu 1987)

Protein binding: SMX: ~70%, TMP: ~44%

Metabolism: Hepatic, both to multiple metabolites; SMX to hydroxy (via CYP2C9) and acetyl derivatives, and also conjugated with glucuronide; TMP to oxide and hydroxy derivatives; the free forms of both SMX and TMP are therapeutically active

Half-life elimination:

TMP: Prolonged in renal failure

Newborns: ~19 hours; range: 11 to 27 hours (Springer 1982)

Infants 2 months to 1 year: ~4.6 hours; range: 3 to 6 hours (Hoppu 1989)

Children 1 to 10 years: 3.7 to 5.5 hours (Hoppu 1987)

Children and Adolescents >10 years: 8.19 hours

Adults: 6 to 11 hours

SMX: 9 to 12 hours, prolonged in renal failure

Time to peak, serum: Oral: 1 to 4 hours

Excretion: Both are excreted in urine as metabolites and unchanged drug

context_chunks.snippet: • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia: Use with caution in patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia and DVT; limb ischemia, necrosis, and gangrene have occurred when warfarin was started or continued after heparin was stopped. Warfarin m…
context_chunks.text:
• Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia: Use with caution in patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia and DVT; limb ischemia, necrosis, and gangrene have occurred when warfarin was started or continued after heparin was stopped. Warfarin monotherapy is contraindicated in the initial treatment of active HIT; warfarin initially inhibits the synthesis of protein C, potentially accelerating the underlying active thrombotic process.

• Hepatic impairment: Reduced liver function, regardless of etiology, may impair synthesis of coagulation factors leading to increased warfarin sensitivity.

• Infection: Use with caution in patients with acute infection or active TB or any disruption of normal GI flora; antibiotics and fever may alter response to warfarin.

• Renal impairment: Use with caution in patients with renal impairment. Patients with renal impairment are at increased risk for bleeding diathesis; frequent INR monitoring is recommended.

• Thyroid disease: Use with caution in patients with thyroid disease; warfarin responsiveness may increase (Ageno 2012).

Special populations:

• Elderly: The elderly may be more sensitive to anticoagulant therapy.

context_chunks.snippet: ALERT: US Boxed Warning  Warfarin interaction:  Frequently monitor the anticoagulant response (international normalized ratio [INR] or prothrombin time [PT]) of patients receiving concomitant capecitabine and oral coumarin-derivative antico…
context_chunks.text:
ALERT: US Boxed Warning

Warfarin interaction:

Frequently monitor the anticoagulant response (international normalized ratio [INR] or prothrombin time [PT]) of patients receiving concomitant capecitabine and oral coumarin-derivative anticoagulant therapy in order to adjust the anticoagulant dose accordingly. A clinically important capecitabine-warfarin drug interaction was demonstrated in a clinical pharmacology trial. Altered coagulation parameters and/or bleeding, including death, have been reported in patients taking capecitabine concomitantly with coumarin-derivative anticoagulants such as warfarin and phenprocoumon. Postmarketing reports have shown clinically significant increases in PT and INR in patients who were stabilized on anticoagulants at the time capecitabine was introduced. These events occurred within several days and up to several months after initiating capecitabine therapy and, in a few cases, within 1 month after stopping capecitabine. These events occurred in patients with and without liver metastases. Age older than 60 years and a diagnosis of cancer independently predispose patients to an increased risk of coagulopathy.

context_chunks.snippet: Mechanical heart valve (aortic or mitral position) to bridge anticoagulation (off-label use): SubQ: 100 units/kg/dose every 12 hours (ACCP [Douketis 2012]). Note: If used in pregnant patients, target anti-Xa level of 0.8 to 1.2 units/mL, 4…
context_chunks.text:
Mechanical heart valve (aortic or mitral position) to bridge anticoagulation (off-label use): SubQ: 100 units/kg/dose every 12 hours (ACCP [Douketis 2012]). Note: If used in pregnant patients, target anti-Xa level of 0.8 to 1.2 units/mL, 4 to 6 hours postdose (AHA/ACC [Nishimura 2014]).

Prevention of recurrent venous thromboembolism in pregnancy (off-label use): SubQ: 5,000 units once daily. Therapy should continue for 6 weeks postpartum in high-risk women (Bates 2012).

Pulmonary embolism, acute (treatment) (noncancer-related) (off-label use): SubQ: 200 units/kg once daily (Kovacs 2000). Note: In patients with VTE and without cancer, oral anticoagulants are preferred over LMWH (unless LMWH is used as initial parenteral anticoagulation prior to dabigatran, edoxaban, or while initiating warfarin) (Kearon 2012; Kearon 2016). In patients transitioning to warfarin, start warfarin on the first treatment day and continue dalteparin until INR is ≥2 for at least 24 hours (usually 5 to 7 days) (ACCP [Guyatt 2012]). Duration of therapy is based on the cause of VTE, risk of recurrence, and risk of bleeding. Refer to guidelines for specific recommendations.

This is because linezolid has MAOI activity, which can increase serotonin levels [chunk_188931::1]. The risk is major, and it is recommended to avoid the combination. If the use of linezolid is unavoidable, close monitoring for signs and symptoms of serotonin syndrome is necessary [chunk_188931::1]. context_chunks.snippet: • Serotonin syndrome: Symptoms of agitation, confusion, hallucinations, hyper-reflexia, myoclonus, shivering, and tachycardia may occur with concomitant proserotonergic drugs, agents which reduce linezolid's metabolism, or in patients with…
context_chunks.text:
• Serotonin syndrome: Symptoms of agitation, confusion, hallucinations, hyper-reflexia, myoclonus, shivering, and tachycardia may occur with concomitant proserotonergic drugs, agents which reduce linezolid's metabolism, or in patients with carcinoid syndrome. Avoid use in such patients unless clinically appropriate and under close monitoring for signs/symptoms of serotonin syndrome or neuroleptic malignant syndrome-like reactions.

• Superinfection: Prolonged use may result in fungal or bacterial superinfection, including C. difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD) and pseudomembranous colitis; CDAD has been observed >2 months postantibiotic treatment.

Disease-related concerns:

• Carcinoid syndrome: Use with caution and closely monitor for serotonin syndrome in patients with carcinoid syndrome; linezolid has not been studied in patients with this condition. Do not use in the absence of close monitoring.

• Diabetes mellitus: Hypoglycemic episodes have been reported; use with caution and closely monitor glucose in diabetic patients. Dose reductions/discontinuation of concurrent hypoglycemic agents or discontinuation of linezolid may be required.

Note: According to treatment guidelines from the Fifth World Symposium on Pulmonary Hypertension (WSPH) and the American College of Chest Physicians (ACCP), continuous IV epoprostenol is recommended as first-line therapy in PAH patients with WHO-FC IV symptoms (ACCP [Taichman 2014]; WSPH [Gailè 2013]).

Use

Acute myocardial infarction: For the management of hemodynamically stable patients with definite or suspected acute MI to reduce cardiovascular mortality.

Angina pectoris caused by coronary atherosclerosis: For the long-term management of patients with angina pectoris.

Hypertension: Treatment of hypertension, alone or in combination with other agents. Note: According to current guidelines for the treatment of high blood pressure in adults, a beta-blocker should only be added to existing antihypertensive therapy when patient is not at goal blood pressure and not used alone (JNC8 [James 2014]).

Guideline recommendations:

Hypertension: The 2014 guideline for the management of high blood pressure in adults (Eighth Joint National Committee [JNC 8]) recommends initiation of pharmacologic treatment to lower blood pressure for the following patients (JNC8 [James, 2014]):

• Patients ≥60 years of age with systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≥150 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure (DBP) ≥90 mm Hg. Goal of therapy is SBP <150 mm Hg and DBP <90 mm Hg.

• Patients <60 years of age with SBP ≥140 mm Hg or DBP is ≥90 mm Hg. Goal of therapy is SBP <140 mm Hg and DBP <90 mm Hg.

context_chunks.snippet: Heart failure: The ACCF/AHA 2013 heart failure guidelines recommend the use of 1 of 3 beta blockers (ie, bisoprolol, carvedilol, or extended-release metoprolol succinate) for all patients with recent or remote history of MI or ACS and reduc…

Heart failure: The ACCF/AHA 2013 heart failure guidelines recommend the use of 1 of 3 beta blockers (ie, bisoprolol, carvedilol, or extended-release metoprolol succinate) for all patients with recent or remote history of MI or ACS and reduced ejection fraction (rEF) to reduce mortality, for all patients with rEF to prevent symptomatic HF (even if no history of MI), and for all patients with current or prior symptoms of HF with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), unless contraindicated, to reduce morbidity and mortality (ACCF/AHA [Yancy 2013]).

Hypertension: The 2014 guideline for the management of high blood pressure in adults (Eighth Joint National Committee [JNC 8]) recommends initiation of pharmacologic treatment to lower blood pressure for the following patients (JNC8 [James 2013]):

• Patients ≥60 years of age, with systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≥150 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure (DBP) ≥90 mm Hg. Goal of therapy is SBP <150 mm Hg and DBP <90 mm Hg.

• Patients <60 years of age, with SBP ≥140 mm Hg or DBP ≥90 mm Hg. Goal of therapy is SBP <140 mm Hg and DBP <90 mm Hg.

Heart failure: Adjunctive treatment of heart failure (HF)

Hypertension: Management of hypertension (monotherapy or in combination with thiazide diuretics).

Guideline recommendations:

Heart failure: The ACCF/AHA 2013 heart failure guidelines recommend the use of ACE inhibitors, along with other guideline directed medical therapies, to prevent HF in patients with a reduced ejection fraction who have a history of MI (stage B HF), to prevent HF in any patient with a reduced ejection fraction (stage B HF), or to treat those with HF and reduced ejection fraction (stage C HFrEF) (ACCF/AHA [Yancy, 2013]).

Hypertension: The 2014 guideline for the management of high blood pressure in adults (Eighth Joint National Committee [JNC 8]) recommends initiation of pharmacologic treatment to lower blood pressure for the following patients:

• Patients ≥60 years with systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≥150 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure (DBP) ≥ 90 mm Hg.

• Patients <60 years with SBP ≥140 mm Hg or DBP is ≥90 mm Hg. Goal of therapy is SBP <140 mm Hg and DBP <90 mm Hg.

• Patients ≥18 years with diabetes and SBP ≥140 mm Hg or DBP ≥90 mm Hg. Goal of therapy is SBP <140 mm Hg and DBP <90 mm Hg.
